petitioner.name: NORTHERN INSURANCE COMPANY OF NEW YORK

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument next in 04-1618, Northern Insurance Company of New York v. Chatham County, Georgia. Mr. Estrada.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Can a county be an arm of the State for some things?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I assume it's -- I assume it's sort of a -- a case-by-case inquiry. In 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 other words, the county could be an arm of the State for some purposes but not others.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Is -- is the failure to 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 extend immunity to counties and municipal entities in a State just a historical relic? It depends on semantics. Or is there some normative or good government policy that dictates the distinction?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: It's just a -- it's just a close textual reading of the Eleventh Amendment. Right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: It says a State. It doesn't say county.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So it's -- it's a matter of respecting the dignity of the States because they participated in the Convention, the plan of Convention?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well -- I -- I guess, in -- in going beyond the Eleventh Amendment, we were appealing to an understanding of sovereignty that existed at the time of the framing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And at the time of the framing, counties in England did not enjoy the -- the sovereign immunity of the king, did they?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So it's a historical relic 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 based on the dignity of the State, or the king in one case, and of corresponding lack of dignity of the entities on the other?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Would you -- would you say thoughtful rather than inflexible? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do you -- do you agree that -- that it's possible that an entity can have sovereign immunity in admiralty where -- where the same entity would -- would not have it elsewhere?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I find that discussion quite perplexing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: They're talking about immunity in most of the cases, not necessarily --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- not necessarily sovereign immunity.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But -- but there is a textual basis for drawing a distinction between admiralty and law and equity. The Eleventh Amendment doesn't extend to -- to admiralty.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Alden tells us what the understanding of the Founders was. Of course, it's the understanding of some of the Founders. It did not include those who were in the majority in Chisholm.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Himmelfarb.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You don't doubt that a county could have sovereign immunity if it qualified as an arm of the State in a particular instance.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Hans -- Hans is residual sovereign immunity.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Some -- some of our brethren don't -- don't agree with it. They don't like the residue and would limit it to the Eleventh Amendment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: If you're going to have a residue, Hans is it I suppose.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Your -- your friend in the -- in the red brief, though, reviews a lot of old cases, suggesting at the time of the founding, that counties were not subject to suit.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Nor could charities. They were immune as well. But it -- it certainly wasn't sovereign immunity.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I ask you this? Supposing a State passed a statute that said that the following counties shall hereby be designated arms of the State and be entitled to immunity, period. Would that provide an adequate defense, do you think?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The question presented is -- is only sovereign immunity, isn't it? It's -- we don't have to decide whether there might be some other type of immunity.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Himmelfarb. Mr. Hart.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Who pays judgments? Who pays judgments against the county?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Hart --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought that was one of the main indicia of whether an entity had been set up as an arm of the State, that is, the State would be directly liable. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, core -- core government functions isn't -- isn't the test either. I mean --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- you know, the Federal Government and I think some States gave -- gave railroads the power to condemn land. Did that make railroads sovereigns entitled to sovereign immunity? don't think so. I

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So the mere fact that -- that your county is exercising some, quote, core government functions, that -- that doesn't -- doesn't get you there.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: That was -- in many of those cases cited in your brief, it was because the duties they were performing they were performing pro bono publico.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And the doctrine extended immunity to them on that basis, not -- not as sovereigns.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It wasn't sovereign immunity. It was -- charities had immunity until very recently. Some States still had it when I was in law school. You couldn't sue a charity for tort.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What -- what other sorts of torts would this apply to, as applied to Chatham County? If Chatham County --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: -- were sued, yes -- if Chatham County were sued for something done by a law enforcement officer, would your theory apply?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, has the Eleventh Circuit or did the old Fifth Circuit ever apply this doctrine in any area outside of admiralty?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What are you relying on in the Georgia constitution? It doesn't mention counties, does it? It just says except as specifically provided in this paragraph, sovereign immunity extends to the State and all of its departments and agencies.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: There can be no -- no -- well, I assume you have a -- a tort -- tort claims act that waives sovereign immunity in some circumstances.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But apart from that, you can't sue counties in tort.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: To what -- what other area would this apply? If the county has sovereign immunity, how about the county school board?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And education would not --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: How about the sanitation department?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, I'm not sure that operating bridges at the time of the framing was a core sovereign function.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: There are an awful lot of private bridges.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, that's bridge immunity, not sovereign immunity. I mean --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- it doesn't come -- it doesn't come within the Federal Constitution.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, no, I'm not talking about textually. I'm talking about in structure. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 There's nothing in the structure that has anything to do with bridges.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I ask this? Are you suggesting that a county could be an arm of the State for some purposes but not for others?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But the -- the court of appeals has said that you weren't asserting that you were an arm of the State. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: All that establishes is simply that if the State were operating this bridge and if the State were on the hook for any judgments and if the State had control over the people who were making the decisions, that there might be an issue of State sovereign immunity.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The whole problem is that it's the county that's doing all that.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, the State doesn't pay the damages.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The State doesn't tell you how to do it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: If it wishes. If it wishes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The State can pay my damages if it wishes. It just doesn't happen to have a statute to that effect right now. But I mean, that -- surely, that doesn't -- doesn't --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But that's a different question. The immunity looks to where the money is going to come from to satisfy a judgment. I don't think it looks to where the funding came from in the first instance.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: It's the claim on the treasury of the judgment that raises the sovereign immunity issues. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What about the South Carolina Supreme Court's opinion in the Hines case which seems to run counter to your argument?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Mr. Hart, may I ask this question? In the -- I noticed the opinion is a per curiam opinion of the Eleventh Circuit. Was the case argued orally in the Eleventh Circuit or was it submitted?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: It was submitted.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The -- the Eleventh Circuit had a prior decision, didn't they?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That was an old Fifth Circuit case --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: It's not unusual that counties maintain and run bridges in your State, is it? I mean, that's --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: That's the normal --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Then -- then how do we know it's a core dignity function of the State if they're -- the normal rule is somebody else does it?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Hart. Mr. Estrada, you have 8 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You're -- are you suggesting that the -- the State would enjoy sovereign immunity in proprietary activities?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But I would have thought, particularly when we're talking about the arm of the State doctrine, that the -- the nature of the activity is one of the key questions we look at.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Maintaining bridges is one thing. You know, operating a for-profit activity would be something else. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I always thought the governmental proprietary distinction really came up in State law cases involving municipal liability. That's principally where it --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
